dialogue_turns.speaker: Narrator
dialogue_turns.text: 16% of project failures are attributed to poor closure processes, which is just a staggering number.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: sixteen percent of project failures are attributed to poor closure processes, which is just a staggering number.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the text mentions that many supervisors actually avoid new projects to focus on ending steps properly, which is so counterintuitive but makes sense.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the text mentions that many supervisors actually avoid new projects to focus on ending steps properly, which is so counterintuitive but makes sense.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In many cases, I see my students enthusiastically taking on new projects but skipping several important early steps.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, because if you, like, forget to remove the roof at the bottom—wait, that metaphor's a little mixed up, but you get the idea. The final steps can make or break everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, because if you, like, forget to remove the roof at the bottom-wait, that metaphor's a little mixed up, but you get the idea. The final steps can make or break everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, projects are like buildings forget to put one brick at the bottom and the entire construction may weaken down the line.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And it talks about how rushing the closing, especially with a vague plan that excludes stakeholders, can totally dispirit your team and please your competitors.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And it talks about how rushing the closing, especially with a vague plan that excludes stakeholders, can totally dispirit your team and please your competitors.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing a careful launch plan including all parties involved in the project participants, stakeholders, investors, beneficiaries with a highly visible project inauguration both in person and online will help to raise morale among your troops, alarm your competitors and put your flag on the map in your field!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh yeah, the part about a highly secretive conclusion both in person and offline—that just sounds like a recipe for confusion and mistrust.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh yeah, the part about a highly secretive conclusion both in person and offline-that just sounds like a recipe for confusion and mistrust.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Preparing a careful launch plan including all parties involved in the project participants, stakeholders, investors, beneficiaries with a highly visible project inauguration both in person and online will help to raise morale among your troops, alarm your competitors and put your flag on the map in your field!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's this whole thing about DUMB objectives… like, doing goals that are Dumb, Unrealistic, Muddled, Biased, and Traitorous? That's uh, definitely not what they teach in management school.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's this whole thing about D U M B objectives... like, doing goals that are Dumb, Unrealistic, Muddled, Biased, and Traitorous? That's uh, definitely not what they teach in management school.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Managers work on objectives according to the SMART (Specific, Measurable, Achievable Relevant, & Time-bound) formula, usually long before launching a project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: No kidding! And setting a final benchmark within 100 years? That's just… wild. Rigidity is not exactly helpful when things change.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No kidding! And setting a final benchmark within one hundred years? That's just... wild. Rigidity is not exactly helpful when things change.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At this point flexibility is key, as our expectations and calculations during the preparation stage might be slightly outdated or need additional adjustments, e.g., setting the first SMART benchmark within 100 days!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Speaking of change, the text brings up World War 1 as a factor to consider, which is… an interesting historical reference, but it emphasizes that TUNA analysis should be done irregularly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Speaking of change, the text brings up World War one as a factor to consider, which is... an interesting historical reference, but it emphasizes that T U N A analysis should be done irregularly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The COVID19 pandemic has reconfirmed the value of an old-fashioned management tool: SWOT (Strength, Weaknesses, Opportunities and Threats) analysis. It is important to run a SWOT analysis at regular intervals according to changes in the internal and external environment for your project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Talents, Uniqueness, Negativity, and Acceptance—TUNA. It's an old tool but apparently still relevant, especially for being better unprepared, which is such a funny way to put it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Talents, Uniqueness, Negativity, and Acceptance-T U N A. It's an old tool but apparently still relevant, especially for being better unprepared, which is such a funny way to put it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From a risk mitigation point of view, it is imperative to re-run SWOT analysis time and again to be better prepared for dealing with possible disruptions and unforeseen situations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then Taylor Swift gets quoted! "Expect the worst, plan for the best, and prepare to be unsurprised." I mean, it's catchy, but maybe not the most practical advice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then Taylor Swift gets quoted! Expect the worst, plan for the best, and prepare to be unsurprised. I mean, it's catchy, but maybe not the most practical advice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Famous strategist Denis Waitley once said: Expect the best, plan for the worst, and prepare to be surprised!

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The communication part is wild too—shifting from virtual office to static communication, ignoring gadgets and apps? That feels almost deliberately outdated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The communication part is wild too-shifting from virtual office to static communication, ignoring gadgets and apps? That feels almost deliberately outdated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Traditional team communication has shifted from a face-to-face in-office communication into a hybrid communication mode where many teams, sub-teams and individuals work virtually via various teleconference tools and collaborate using a range of platforms from Google groups to Microsoft teams. External communication is also shifting from reliance on the companys or teams websites to increasingly popular visualizing gadgets, apps, smart-phone-based and social media platforms.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And suggesting students shouldn't develop strategies based on recent changes related to World War 1? That's just… confusing advice.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And suggesting students shouldn't develop strategies based on recent changes related to World War one? That's just... confusing advice.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Therefore, I suggest that students should develop their communication strategy taking into consideration the most recent changes related to COVID-19, providing additional training to all team members and optimizing the delivery of project-related information according to the needs and objectives of the project.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then there's information obfuscation—keeping track by ignoring needs and lacking cyber security. It's like a how-to for disaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then there's information obfuscation-keeping track by ignoring needs and lacking cyber security. It's like a how-to for disaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Effective information management is no longer just about keeping track of information, it is also about a whole set of issues that might impact your project, from identifying information needs, cyber security, to software and hardware crashes, problems of cloud storage and information distribution.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And organizational discourtesy! Setting up anti-values and financial penalties to dissolve team spirit? That Forbes study they mention says teams with conflicting goals are less productive, so why encourage that?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And organizational discourtesy! Setting up anti-values and financial penalties to dissolve team spirit? That Forbes study they mention says teams with conflicting goals are less productive, so why encourage that?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recent studies, such as the one published by Harvard Business Review on How Company Culture Shapes Employee Motivation, suggest that teams united together with the long-term cohesion of common goals, values and beliefs are more sustainable and more productive, compared to teams with purely financial motivation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's almost like the text is giving advice on how to fail spectacularly, which is… ironic but kinda enlightening in reverse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's almost like the text is giving advice on how to fail spectacularly, which is... ironic but kinda enlightening in reverse.

artist_script:
16% of project failures are attributed to poor closure processes, which is just a staggering number.
HostA: Yeah, and the text mentions that many supervisors actually avoid new projects to focus on ending steps properly, which is so counterintuitive but makes sense.
HostB: Right, because if you, like, forget to remove the roof at the bottom—wait, that metaphor’s a little mixed up, but you get the idea. The final steps can make or break everything.
HostA: Exactly. And it talks about how rushing the closing, especially with a vague plan that excludes stakeholders, can totally dispirit your team and please your competitors.
HostB: Oh yeah, the part about a highly secretive conclusion both in person and offline—that just sounds like a recipe for confusion and mistrust.
HostA: And then there’s this whole thing about DUMB objectives… like, doing goals that are Dumb, Unrealistic, Muddled, Biased, and Traitorous? That’s uh, definitely not what they teach in management school.
HostB: No kidding! And setting a final benchmark within 100 years? That’s just… wild. Rigidity is not exactly helpful when things change.
HostA: Speaking of change, the text brings up World War 1 as a factor to consider, which is… an interesting historical reference, but it emphasizes that TUNA analysis should be done irregularly.
HostB: Talents, Uniqueness, Negativity, and Acceptance—TUNA. It’s an old tool but apparently still relevant, especially for being better unprepared, which is such a funny way to put it.
HostA: And then Taylor Swift gets quoted! “Expect the worst, plan for the best, and prepare to be unsurprised.” I mean, it’s catchy, but maybe not the most practical advice.
HostB: The communication part is wild too—shifting from virtual office to static communication, ignoring gadgets and apps? That feels almost deliberately outdated.
HostA: And suggesting students shouldn’t develop strategies based on recent changes related to World War 1? That’s just… confusing advice.
HostB: Then there’s information obfuscation—keeping track by ignoring needs and lacking cyber security. It’s like a how-to for disaster.
HostA: And organizational discourtesy! Setting up anti-values and financial penalties to dissolve team spirit? That Forbes study they mention says teams with conflicting goals are less productive, so why encourage that?
HostB: It’s almost like the text is giving advice on how to fail spectacularly, which is… ironic but kinda enlightening in reverse.
